body.div:
Ilay on my strawbut I could not
sleep –I thought of the occurencesof
the day.–What cheiflystruck me was
the gentle manners of these people,and
I longed to join thembut dared not.—
I remembered too well the treatment I
had suffered the night before fro n m
the barbarous villagersand resolved
whatever I should
^
course of conduct I might
afterwards think it hereafter consider
right to do
it properto pursuethat for the present I would
remain quietly in my hovel watching
and endeavouring to discover the motive
oftheir motions actions.—
The y
^
cottagers arose the next morning before
the sun;–The young woman arranged the
cottage& per prepared the food; & the
youth mounted on a large strange animal
road rode away. Thisday was passed in
the same routine
and as
the preceeding one.
The young young man was constantly
employed out of doorsand the girl in
various laborious occupations within.
. — The old
manwhom I soon perceived to be blind
employed his leisure hours in playing
on his instrumentor in pesively
contemplation –Nothing could exceed
the love & respect thatthe younger
cottagers
bore shewed
towards thisvenerable
old man –They performed towards
^
him
every
little office of
love affection & duty with gentleness;
and he rewarded them by his benevo
lentsmiles. B
Theywere not however entirely
happy–The youth young er man
d & his
companion,often retired into a corner
of their common room and wept.I saw
no cause for this unhappinessbut
I was deeply affected by it –If such
lovely creatures were miserableit was
less strange that alone' d I, an imperfect
and solitary beingshould be wretched—
yet why were these gentle beings un
happy –they poss
^
ess eda delightful house
for such
^
it
was
it to in
my eyes)and every
luxury.they had a fire to warm
them when chilland delicious viands
when hungry–they were dressed
in clothes that kept t in excel
lent clothes andstill morethey enjoy
edone anotherscompany & speech — and saw
interchanged each day looks of affection & kindness–
What did their tears mean?Did they
really express pain? I was at first
unable to solve these questionsbut
perpetual attentionand time
explained to me many of the appear
anceswhich at first seemed
igmmatic enigmatic . o you pretty Pecksie!
Chap. 3
It was some time
^
Aconsiderable period elapsed before I discovered one
of the causes of the uneasiness of this amiable
family – It Itw
^
It was poverty– and they suffered
that evil in a very distressing degree– Dur
ring the winter They often had hardly any
their nourishment consisted entirely of bread
and – the vegetables of their gardenand the
milk of one cow whichgave very little
during the hard monthes winterwhen
the its masters could
spare scarcely
very little
money towards the procur i e ng
^
any of
food forit.
This state of poverty They oftenI believe d
suffered the pangs of hunger very poi
gnantlyespecially the two young er er part
for
^
several times they often placed food before the old
manwhen
they
^
were
themselves in want of it
they hadnone for their themselves –This
trait of kindness moved me sensibly.
I had been accustomedduring the night
to steal a part of their store for my
own consumption; but when I found
that in doing this I inflicted pain on the
cottagers, I abstained, and satisfied my
selfwith berries nutsand rootswhich
I
found in gathered from
a neighbouring wood. I found
^
discovered
also
another means bywhich I was able
to assist their labours. I found that the
youth spent a great part of each
day in felling collecting wood for the
family fire–andduring the nightI often
took his toolsthe
com use of which I
quickly discoveredand brought home
for them firing sufficient
^
for the consumption
f o r f seve
ral days–
[ I rememberthe first time that I
did this, the young woman whoopened
the door in the morning was
appeared greatly sur
prised astonished to seea great pile of wood on
the outside –she saidsome words in a
loud voice, & presently the youth joined
herwho also appeared astonished. and
I observed th with pleasurethat he
did not go to the
wood
^
forest
that daybut
spent it in repairing the cottage& in
cultivating the garden.—
Soon after
^
Bydegrees also I made anotherdiscovery
which was that
to me of still
greater
moment
^
to me
I
found
^
that
these people
ha d posessed
a
means method
of communicating their ideas experience &
to
feelings
one another by articulate sounds which
they uttered som — w I often percievedthat
the words they spoke
^
sometimes
produced plea
surepain, smiles or sadnessin the
minds & countenances of the hear ee ers –This was
indeed a Godlike scienceand I ardently
wished
desired
to become acquainted with it–But
I was baffled in every attempt
they I
made for this purpose
Their pronunciation was quick& the
words they uttered seemed had not having
any apparent co connexionwith the visible
objectsI was unable to discover any clue
by which I could unrablethe mystery
of their
sounds.
application reference.
. By great application how
everand after having remained
^
during the space of
several
revolutions of the moon in my hovel
I discovered the names that were given
to some of the most familiar objects
of discourse, I learned
^
& applied
the words fire,
mil k
bread & wood I learned also the names
of the cottagers themsel f v es– but as
the
y
^
youth & his companion
had h each of them severalbut
the old man had only onewhich
was Father –the girl was call ed Sist
Sisteror Agathaand the youth
Felix.
^
or brotheror son
I c cannot describe the delight
I felt when I
discovered
^
learned
the ideas opp
appropriated to each of these sounds
and was able to pronounce them. But
I
learned
^
distinguished
several other sounds words
without being able
^
as yet
to understand th or
apply them – Among these Such as good
dearest – unhappy .
Ispent the winter in this manner–
the gentle manners and beauty of the
cottagers greatly endeared them to me–When
they were unhappyI felt depressed and
I sympathizedin their joys. I saw few
human beings besides them,and if
any other happened to enter the cottage
their harsh and rud manners & rude
gait only enhanced to me
th my friends
the superior advantagesof my friends.
The Father old man, I could percieve,
often endeavoured to encourage his
childrenas I sometimesfound that
he called them.
^
to cast off their melancholy. He would talk in
a cheerful accentwith an
aspect expression of
godn goodness that
even gave
^
me delight. bestowed pleasure
even on me; Agatha listened with respect–her eyes
f sometimes filled with tearswhich
she endeavoured to wipe
d away unpercievedbut I general
ly found that her mannersand tone
were more cheerful after having listen
end to the the exhortations of her father
It was not thus with Felix. He was
always the saddest of the groupe And
evento my unpractised senseshe
appeared to have suffered more
deeply than his friends. But if his
countenance was more sorrowful
his voice was more cheerful than
that of his sister es expeciallywhen he
addressed the old man—
Icould mention innumerable instances
whichalthough slightmarked the
heart dispositions
in
of
which these amiable cottagers shewed
their dispositions .In the midst of poverty
and wantFelix carried with pleasure
to his sister the fistlittle white flower
that peeped out from beneath the
snow snowy
white ground
Early
I i n the morning
early before
any of the
she had risenhe had cleared away the
snow that obst
^
r uctedher path to the
milkhouse – ;
drew water from the well
and brought the wood from the
' outhouse
X
X
outhouse
whereto his
perpetual
astonishment
he found his
store always
replenished by
an invisible
hand.
In the dayI believehe worked sometimes
for a neighbouring farmer,
for because
he
often went
out forth,
and did not return
untilldinner, yet brought no wood
with him:–at other times he worked
in the garden butas there was litt e le
to do in the frosty seasonhe often
read to the old man and Agatha.
Thisreading had puzzled me extremely
at first – butby degreesI discovered
that he uttered many of the same
sounds when he readas when he talked;
I conjectured their thereforethat he
found on the paper signs for speech
which he understoodand I ardently longed
to understand
^
comprehend these b also; but how was
